title: 110_s1023
content: ELIMINATION OF REMAINDER OF SCHIP FUNDING SHORTFALLS FOR FISCAL YEAR 2007. The amendment to the Social Security Act eliminates the remainder of fiscal year 2007 funding shortfalls by providing additional amounts to states to cover the estimated shortfalls. The amendment to the Social Security Act addresses funding shortfalls for fiscal year 2007 by providing additional funds to states with approved State child health plans. The amendment to the Social Security Act provides additional funds to states with approved State child health plans for fiscal year 2007, including redistribution amounts and appropriation authority. Conforming amendments are made to Section 2104(h) of the Act. Amendment to Section 2104(h) of the Social Security Act includes changes to paragraphs (1)(B), (2)(B), (5)(A), and (6) regarding redistribution and allotment of funds. The funding provisions are outlined in Section 2. The Medicaid Program now requires the use of tamper-resistant prescription pads for covered outpatient drugs to prevent fraud. This amendment applies to prescriptions executed after September 30, 2007. The amendment repeals a provision for certain beneficiaries under the Medicare Advantage Program, with an effective date after the enactment of the amendment. The amendment repeals a provision for certain beneficiaries under the Medicare Advantage Program, with an effective date after the enactment of this Act. It denies payments for hospital or ambulatory surgical center services that directly harm patients. The amendment repeals a provision for certain beneficiaries under the Medicare Advantage Program, denying payments for hospital or ambulatory surgical center services that directly harm patients. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can apply "never events" lists determined by a consensus process involving clinicians, quality experts, health care providers, and patients. The amendment repeals provisions in the Social Security Act related to Medicare Advantage Program beneficiaries, denying payments for certain harmful hospital or surgical center services. The Secretary of Health and Human Services can use "never events" lists determined by a consensus process involving various healthcare stakeholders. The amendment to the Social Security Act allows for public disclosure of "never events" to inform the medical community about safety issues. Effective immediately upon enactment, it includes denial of payments for specific harmful services. The amendment to the Social Security Act denies payments for specific harmful services, including inpatient hospital services for discharges after October 1, 2007, and outpatient hospital services and facility services in an ambulatory surgical center after January 1, 2008.
